author: @statquest
text: NOTE: If you are still wondering why we add rarer events to the p-value, consider this: At the start of the video I got 2 heads and though, "wow! This is special!!!". However, if I got 2 tails, I would have thought the exact same thing. We tend to think that whatever we see is special, even though there are other events that are just as rare, or rarer. Adding them to the p-value compensates for our observational bias.  Support StatQuest by buying my book The StatQuest Illustrated Guide to Machine Learning or a Study Guide or Merch!!! https://statquest.org/statquest-store/

author: @koiRitwikHai
text: 5:11 you are adding the probability of observing something else that is equally rare... isn't it another way of saying "just double the probability" ? P(x) + P(y) + P(z) where P(y) = P(x) and P(z) < P(x) so why not 2*P(x) + P(z) ?  or is the following correct formulation of p-value $ p-value = P(x) + \sum_{j}^{J} P(j) + \sum_{k}^{K} P(k) \\ where \\ \forall j \in J; P(j) = P(x) \\ \forall k \in K; P(k) < P(x) \\ J, K \subset S $ you can visualize here https://latexeditor.lagrida.com/  Update: The above logic is incorrect. Rareness is not measured by probability. Sample x is considered as rarer than sample s not because P(x) < P(s). It is considered as rarer because our null hypothesis says so. Imagine the null hypothesis as a stubborn person (named Nallu) who claims this â€œThe superdrug did not help people recover in fewer days.â€. You go to him and say, â€œI recovered in 15 daysâ€. Nallu will say, â€œokay.. That proves my pointâ€. Bob comes and says, â€œI recovered in 16 daysâ€. Nallu will say, â€œaaha I was right thenâ€. But then John says, â€œI recovered in 14 daysâ€. Nallu will say, â€œhuhâ€¦ that is rareâ€. Mary comes and says, â€œI recovered in 11 daysâ€. Nallu will say, â€œhuhâ€¦ I would still say The superdrug did not help people recover in fewer days. So what you observed is rarer.â€ And so on.

author: @karannchew2534
text: Notes for future revision.  Probability of an event is NOT the same as the p-value of the event.  Probability of getting two heads = 0.25 p-value of getting two heads = 0.5  = prob of event + prob of other event equally rare + prob of other event more rare  = 0.25 + 0.25 + 0 = 0.5  p-value is about how 'rare' or how 'special' an event is. aka how 'significant' an event is.

author: @josippardon8933
text: I think I have better explanation for why p-value is sum of all these things. Lets go:  Null hypothesis = "Even though I got 2 heads in a row, my coin is no different from normal coin"  Our event = We got 2 heads in a row.  Under the assumption that null hypothesis is true, what is the probability of event rarer than ours or equaly rare? It is 0.25 + 0.25 + 0 = 0.5 (this is p-value).  That essentialy means that probability of getting event rarer than ours or equaly rare is pretty big (50% exactly), which means that our event is not so shocking.   What if our p-value was 0.01? That would mean that probability of getting event rarer or equaly rare is practicaly impossible, which means that our event is very shocking. We got event that is practicaly the rarest, there are no rarer events. So, under our assumption, we got event that is practicaly the rarest, which is very unlikely. It more likely that our assumption is wrong.  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Which probabilites we consider to be "practicaly impossible"? Ones that are lower than alfa. For example, if alfa = 0.1, we would consider probability of 0.07 to be "practicaly impossible".

author: @darsh29
text: Typically Alpha=0.05 (The significance level) . H0 is rejected if p-value < alpha. (ie its statistically significant or statistically different from zero (or someothervalue depending on the null hypothesis). We fail to Reject the Null hypothesis if  p-value > alpha  ie  statistically insignificant at the alpha % level. In statistical packages like STATA by default p-values are for two-sided tests. p-value (for one sided test) = 0.5* p-value (for 2 sided test)

text: In the example with height of Brazilian women, you concluded that randomly observing a woman who is 141cm tall would be considered rare. However, what if we'd consider a different event: observing someone who is 140.9cm to 141 cm tall. Then the null hypothesis would be that it is not unusual to observe someone of that height. author: @mauliknaik9520
text: Hi Josh,  Many thanks for this video, it is super helpful. To reinforce my understanding, a lot depends on how we define our Hypothesis. For example, we have 3 different hypothesis to test:  Option 1 - My coin is not biased towards Heads (basically we do not care if it is biased towards Tails) Option 2 - My coin is not biased (which is what we  talk about in the video with the coin example) Option 3 - My coin is not biased towards Tails (basically we do not care if it is biased towards Heads)  So, as per my understanding all the above will different p-value for the same experiment outcome, right? Option 1 and Option 3 can be treated as one tail testing and Option 2 is the two tail where we are concerned about both the extremes and rarer events on both sides.  Do let me know your views!  And as always a SUPER FAN of your videos.  Best Regards, Maulik

author: @ellenpasternack9750
text: Richard Feynman once said something that I think helps to conceptualise why we include things that are equally rare in the p-value:  "You know, the most amazing thing happened to me tonight... I saw a car with the license plate ARW 357. Can you imagine? Of all the millions of license plates in the state, what was the chance that i would see that particular one tonight? Amazing!"   In this example it is easy to see that, although the chance of seeing that particular numberplate is tiny, any other numberplate you could have seen would by definition have been exactly as rare. It would be impossible to have any observation less rare. Therefore the observation is not remarkable at all unless we have something else to say about it.

author: @stargrass214
text: Hmmm at 18:57, you mentioned all the heights < 155.4 are more extreme than heights in between 155.4 to 156.0. I am not too sure if I understand "extreme" correctly.  I guess using an extreme case like a uniform distribution probably can clear my confusion.... What if it was a test for uniform distribution that starts from 0 to 1 with a constant probablity density value of 1. If i got a mean of say 0.3 in my sample, the p-value would be 1 and if the mean of my sample is greater than 1, then the p-value would be 0?  My understanding goes for continous variable, "more extreme" refers to the interval whose maximum value of the probablity density function is less than the value of that for population mean (although the value of a single point is meaningless for continous random variables); and for discrete variables, it is simpler - "more extreme" refers to any point whose value of probablity mass function less than that of the mean.  I wish my understanding is correct...hopefully a BAM too...Thanks for anyone who could help here :)

author: @Harish-ou4dy
text: Hello, while calculating the p-value, the second and third part which amounts to equally rare and even rarer events can be any part in the distribution graph. For example, heights shorter than 145 cm is 2.5% of the total do is height between any two larger numbers like 151 cm to 152.2 which might cover area 2.5% of the total distribution. So, adding 2.5% of every consecutive small block will sum up to 1 no matter which even you choose.

author: @peshalgoel7414
text: Best Explanation Ever!!  To put it the other way: For an event A to be special, there should be very few events rarer than event A. So, the sum of probabilities of getting events equally rare or rarer than event A should be as low as possible. We decide that threshold to be 5%.  or there should be a lot of events much more common than Event A for it to be special/unusual. In this case, more is the sum of probabilities of getting events equally common or more common than Event A, more special is the Event A. Logically the threshold here seems to be 95%.  Did I get it right?

author: @clydebelasso5826
text: Hi Josh, I have a small question to ask. In some statistical analysis programs, we sometimes set a p-value rather than calculate it. Suppose you have two events, A and B, and you wanted to know whether both events had the same contribution to an outcome, or if event A was a main contributor to an outcome rather than event B. What would it mean if we were to set a p-value of 0.001 in a one sided test for example?

author: @statquest
text: NOTE: If you are still wondering why we add rarer events to the p-value, consider this: At the start of the video I got 2 heads and though, "wow! This is special!!!". However, if I got 2 tails, I would have thought the exact same thing. We tend to think that whatever we see is special, even though there are other events that are just as rare, or rarer. Adding them to the p-value compensates for our observational bias.
